intro: Calendula sancta subsp. cristagalli, commonly known as the Sicilian marigold, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its vibrant yellow to orange flower heads. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and showy, daisy-like flowers. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy and drought-tolerant species. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for ornamental gardening and traditional herbal uses.
